Review: so the one legged jockey said...
Review_Url: This morning I woke up smiling and that was due to watching this film the night before. I hadn't seen this in quite some time, but Lord knows how many times I have in my lifetime and some of it can still make me laugh out loud. This tale of two musicians dressed as women in an all girl band due to running from jazz age gangsters has many times been called the greatest comedy ever made. It may not get the laughs it once did, but it probably deserves that title. Despite the endless tales of the difficulties in filming it, there is just nothing wrong with it. It is smart, funny, well acted, superbly written and it just gets better as it rolls along. This is not Marilyn Monroe's best performance, but she is perfect for the role and this is definitely the best film she was ever in. She truly dazzles. Tony Curtis does well as one half of this drag duo, but he is no match for the comedic talents of his co-star, Jack Lemmon, who is sensational. Lemmon had one of the greatest careers in Hollywood, won two Oscars, but for my money, this may be his finest hour in a career full of them. Thanks to him, the writing and directing, the upper berth and engagement scenes are among the gems in the history of Hollywood film comedies. This film just never gets old. It is simply a comic masterpiece from the great Billy Wilder whose direction was nominated for an Oscar, but not the film itself, one of the most glaring omissions in the Academy's history, though they have quite a few of them and this one is near the very top. It's wonderful.

Review_Url: There is a number of movies which may be considered to attain the same level of super-masterpiece as "Some Like it Hot", showing that cinema can really be great art. In movie history, it is impossible to overcome it in the quality of the story, of the photography, of the costumes, of the music, of the direction, of the performances and charisma of the actors, of the careful and evocative reconstruction of the roaring twenties. What about the script? This is beyond any description, pure art, work of genius at his highest level. OK, the plot is not realistic... well, is Mozart's "Magic Flute" realistic? Some works of art are just not involved with realism. I deliberately pass over the fact that Wilder's masterpiece is also one of the funniest movies ever made: art may be tragic or comic or what else. It doesn't matter: it remains art. Author: 2 November 2009
Review: Some Like It Hot on Reel 13
Review_Url: It's interesting to me that, for a movie that is essentially silly and contrived at heart, SOME LIKE IT HOT works so well and holds up even today. I mean, as I'm sure you've heard if you've watched Thirteen at all this week, AFI recently named SOME LIKE IT HOT as the greatest American comedy of all-time. If the same movie were made today, I'm not sure it would fly. In today's more liberated society, men dressing up as women isn't that much of a novelty and it is my opinion that modern audiences would reject the coincidences that the plot hinges on (Lemmon and Curtis actually witness the St. Valentine's Day Massacre AND the mob chasing them just happens to show up at the same hotel in Florida!). However, because it is from the fifties and in black and white, today's audiences tend to be a little more accepting, as if to assume that's they way things were done back then.

Author: 17 April 2004
Review_Url: Some Like It Hot? How about some like it perverted! This is surprisingly a very sexual driven movie, especially for the era. The movie is very sneaky with the dirty jokes. Some Like It Hot is about two men ( Joe and Jerry) on the run from the mob. They end up in disguise in none other than women's clothes to escape from the mob. Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon did great playing females! A little too well. They were a great comedic duo and made the film funny. Who didn't need to be in the film is Marilyn Monroe who played Sugar the girl that Joe and Jerry of course fall for. The Sugar character is funny, but the casting director could have most likely found someone better than Marilyn Monroe. The only reason they should have Marilyn in the film is because of the music. She did do well singing the cute yet sultry songs that were in the movie.  It's hard to believe Marilyn Monroe was such an icon in that decade and still is today. Yes, she is pretty, but her acting skills were not great in this movie. It seemed like she was forcing the lines and facial expressions out. The plot is predictable now, but most likely in the 50's it wasn't predictable since it was very risky. It is not the funniest film ever but funny enough to at least see once. Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon's comedic talents were the highlight of the movie, but unfortunately Marilyn's bad acting skills somewhat ruined the film. This movie is a 7/10.

Review_Url: The 1959, Romantic Comedy Classic, Some Like It Hot, starring Marilyn Monroe, Tony Curtis, and Jack Lemmon, tells a story in times of sociological pressures of perfection and conceptualism of the structure of society. 1959 marked the beginning of, what we would later call, LGBT communities. The approach to submitting a movie that promotes tolerance towards cross dressing and ultimately the idea of homosexuality, is done with impeccable timing. To set the movie in earlier era allows for the viewer to think that such a tolerance was being upheld in that specific time era. Perpetuating for the allowance in the era to date. Film stood to put the war behind. This film did so, with a concentrated focus of enlightenment derived and depicted through the life of struggling musicians. The movie depicted an era where individuals could be anything/anyone. They were able to swap their former lives for the life of luxury. Music was becoming even more popular across the country. The all women's band represented female independence as well as equality. This was an era of times for embarking on a journey of self-discovery and rebellion, which was depicted by the character Sugar. Sugar was a runaway with the hopes of a life change through marriage. Flirtatiousness and drinking were deviant in the eyes of society. However, depicted with finesse and naturality in this romantic comedy. My favorite line of the movie was in the last scene. Two words precedent to the entire film, "...nobody's perfect."

Review_Url: One of the most bold, clever, and hilarious comedies I have ever had the pleasure of watching! A film that made a choice that many would have considered a bit "too ambitious" or " too outrageous" for when it was made that choice being having two men dress and act like women. I definitely feel the idea of cross-dressing would be more acceptable in today's world despite some of society's/culture's differences on the matter, but making a choice such as cross-dressing back in 1959 was a very bold move. The story of the film is a cleverly written piece a comedy gold which combines not only humor but wit, amusement, and great direction. The comedy genre is probably one of the hardest genres to become acclaimed by both critics and audiences, whereas, other genres like dramas some times have easier when it comes being considered an acclaiming film. A well written script and dialogue exchanges all culminate into enjoyable performances from Monroe, Lemmon, Curtis and the rest the secondary cast members.

Author: 22 October 2005
Review_Url: I was 11 years old when this film was made, and I remember bunking in to our local cinema in London to see it!I'd been smitten by Marilyn a couple of years before after accidentally seeing her in the easily forgettable Prince And the Showgirl when my family went to the movies on a wet holiday afternoon in Ramsgate! I got the idea of the men dressing as women, in order to escape mob execution, but to discover at the end one of them was prepared to go through with the charade in order to "marry" a rich playboy, who'd been quite taken with him/her, I was disgusted! I now have this movie in my library at home and have watched it enough times to form the impression that these two guys actually enjoyed their predicament! I recall watching another film made in the same era, where Tony Curtis played a slave to the Laurence Olivier Roman nobleman, in which the latter was explaining that some people like oysters and some like snails, but it was possible to like both! Was this just a subtle attempt to tell the public, it's OK to live in both worlds? Even so, this was quite a presentable show piece, and was all the better for displaying the delightful Marilyn Monroe, who would've lit up any boring script.For this I give 7 out of 10.

Author: 23 July 2008
Review_Url: Ever since I first viewed this film in 1983, I found this this film funny but not as riotous as others found it to be. Now, 25 years later, I still find this film overrated. For years, I've been trying to figure out why. Now I'm attempting to articulate my feelings for this comedy, for it's another "classic" film which needs its merits re-examined. This film has a terrific comic premise, but it didn't need to be dragged out for two hours. Any film with a farcical tone risks losing sustaining power with a long running time. One other film which died under its own weight was the three-hour-plus "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World", whose success ultimately rested on its cast, a mixture of serious actors(Spencer Tracy, for one), good(Sid Caesar, Jonathan Winters, etc.)and mediocre comic actors(Ethel Merman anybody?). Then again, director Stanley Kramer isn't famous for his comic gifts. Now for the cast of "Some Like It Hot". No blame will be heaped upon Tony Curtis & Jack Lemmon, whose performances in & out of drag justifies the positive reputation of this film; in fact, this film screeches to halt whenever either of them is off-screen. As for Marilyn Monroe, I enjoyed her singing; otherwise, I found her miscast in this film. The role of Sugar Kane needed someone with an unquestionably stronger sense of self than Monroe was capable of projecting here. Her frequently reported unprofessional behavior off-screen is all too evident here within this film; sadly, it would be the beginning of the end for her career and her life. Nevertheless, her name meant big box office for the film, and it is forever preserved on this film; however, there is no accounting for taste in what the public finds sexy, then or now. As for the rest of the cast, the only other actors who showed comic timing were Joan Shawlee as Sweet Sue and Joe E. Brown as Lemmon's romantic partner Osgood Fielding. Too bad the same couldn't be said for either George Raft or Pat O'Brien. I'm sure neither of them were hired for being funny, yet it's too bad director Billy Wilder didn't allow either of them to deliver his dialog with a little tongue-in-cheek. But Raft & O'Brien stop the film in its tracks, and that is symptomatic of a film farce lacking in any sense of pacing. Any good film farce needs to move, but this one stagnates and lumbers about.

Author: 10 August 2017
Review: Still hot after all these years
Review_Url: This movie has not aged; it's still wonderful, full of laughs and surprises. The violence is handled well, almost as slapstick, and Marilyn thoroughly deserved her Best Actor award. The friendship and tension between Curtis and Lemmon helps carry the story, as does Joe E Brown as the fourth corner in this love triangle, but the real star is writer Billy Wilder. The dialog is perfect, probably the result of endless rewrites. Osgood gets the final line, "Well - nobody's perfect" but the script continues, hinting at a sequel: "But that's another story - and we're not quite sure the public is ready for it."

Author: 19 January 2022
Review_Url: Some Like it Hot is a truly delightful and hilarious comedy with brilliant acting and a great script. It's the kind of comedy where the desire for sex is part of the story, and while there were movies that ignored it, this movie uses it to amazing effect. The plot is brilliantly constructed and almost thought out: two men escape after witnessing a mob fight and join a women's group disguised as women, and this is where the film gets tricky. Billy Wilder's direction is impeccable, the cinematography is beautiful, and the music is superb. The real treasure, apart from the performances, is the script, full of classically delightful lines that are not only funny but also smart. The performances are just perfect, while Tony Curtis and Jack Curtis gave really great roles, it was the beautiful Marilyn Monroe, in a delightfully seductive and sly performance, who stole the acting honors. Overall, this is a really great comedy that ranks alongside comedies like Duck Soup and Night at the Opera as one of the best comedies of all time.

Review_Url: "Some Like It Hot" is supposed to be the funniest movie of all time; I cannot disagree, the movie is hilarious. The trouble starts when Jack Lemon and Tony Curtis witness the St. Valentine's Day Massacre and must go into hiding to save their lives. The only escape is joining an all girls' orchestra that is leaving for Florida. It is here that they encounter Marilyn Monroe and vie for her attentions, though they are dressed as women. The plot thickens when they reach their destination and grows more comical. The acting in the film is top notch, including the performances given by actors other than the stars of the movie.

Author: 3 September 2018
Review_Url:
Some Like It Hot is a comedy in which it shows how two men (Curtis and Lemmon) have to flee from a mafia band that wants to kill them after having witnessed a horrible crime. Meanwhile, they learn that an orchestra composed solely of women is looking for two components to join them. At first they think that it is not a very viable option, but given their economic situation and the mafia that persecutes them, they do not hesitate to join the musical group disguising themselves as women to go unnoticed. During their stay with the orchestra they will meet Sugar Kane (Marilyn Monroe), the singer of the group and a very passionate young woman.
This film, true masterpiece of the director Billy Wilder, is one of the best comedies thanks to its protagonists Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon in which the viewer can have fun all the time. In addition, the fabulous performance of Marilyn Monroe is the icing on the cake and thanks to it has become one of her most famous films. What this film has lacked is that it be in color.
